57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (00:28): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: AP + dual-enrollment course credits :-)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (00:28): 57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450: We need more i18n here.
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (00:28): 57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450: You may have o convert to non-US :)

a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (00:29): 57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450: en-gb-x-sneddy, or en-gb-oed if you can't manage the former
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (00:30): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: Presumably your university will just be en-gb unless you plan to self educate
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (00:30): ah, so someone who can understand me if I refer to the subjunctive mood?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (00:30): I thought 57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 meant what language to localize to :P
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (00:31): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: That's making the assumption I go to the UK :)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (00:31): 57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450: Only possibly
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (00:34): 57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450: Why would en-gb-* people be better at grammar than anyone else?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (00:34): Oh. Well I guess that he could look it up then
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (00:35): But we have essentially no education in grammar here
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (00:35): just like an en-us-x-harvard would understand it but not an en-us-x-hillbilly
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (00:35): My parents own a paper copy of the "compact" OED, which is basically the same as the full OED just printed in 8pt type with four normal OED pages to the page
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (00:36): Hooray for www.oed.com

a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (00:38): 57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450: ("only possibly" because the OED merely defines words in terms of other words, and eventually falls about with recursive definitions, so it isn't certain I can understand anything)
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (00:38): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: Hooray for university subscriptions to hugely expensive reference works
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (00:38): I use dictionary.oed.com through school's proxy
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (00:39): needs to write his personal statement
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (00:39): sighs
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (00:39): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: and for SSH proxying so I can access it from home
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (00:39): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: Yeah, that's cool too
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (00:39): only discovered that recently
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (00:40): I also know whatever I write in the first draft of it will be completely thrown out and rewritten as I over-edit it.

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (00:40): though usually I'm lazy and use rdesktop to a Windows machine instead, because that's easier than complicated port forwarding and faster than simple X forwarding

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (00:43): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: In that case you can fill your first draft with jokes and terrible puns and obvious fabrications, which will make it more interesting
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (00:43): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: But only make the first draft more interesting.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (00:43): That's better than nothing
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (00:44): Which will result in the second draft being what the first draft normally is :)
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (00:44): I wrote on of my college apps the night it was due grumbling about it in IRC

a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (00:45): But I may end up applying to MIT and Stanford‚Ä¶
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (00:46): didn't like Stanford's campus, and there was a certain haughtiness on the staff's part as well
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (00:46): then again, it seems that every American university's admissions director
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (00:47): has the disadvantage of being unlikely to be able to see either before going there
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (00:47): s' job is to try to make it seem like you can't get in
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (00:47): Hey the OED is 50% cheaper in the USA!
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (00:47): but our money is twice as cheap as yours...
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (00:48): I sent an email asking one or two questions to MIT Admissions, the reply I got had a reassuring start: "Hello Geoggrey,"
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (00:48): curses the until-recently negative average savings rate
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (00:48): wonders where else is better than Cambridge for Comp.Sci.
57d876083caf517f49e8cf5e03307450 (00:49): and lack of fiscal sanity on the part of elected officials, but you can't have it all

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (00:49): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: Whilst I may not be sampling the ull distribution function, all the MIT people I have met have been both excepionally bright and excepionally nice

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (00:50): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: I don't think there exists a total ordering of the goodness of universities, so it doesn't make sense to ask if somewhere is "better" than somewhere else :-p

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:02): that avenue sure looked nice
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (01:03): apply to Stanford, CMU, MIT and Berkeley
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (01:03): and study CompSci at one of those
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (01:03): 042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427: Berkeley is near-impossible to get into as an international student
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:03): yeah if you're going to do compsci then those are the ones to do it at
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (01:03): ok the other three
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (01:03): Carnegie Mellon University
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (01:03): the best CompSci program that the average person hasn't heard of
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (01:04): Pittsburgh‚Ä¶ I think I went there.
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (01:04): but it's as good as the other big three
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (01:04): (I went to the USA once when I was five, I don't remember that much)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (01:04): (I remember I don't like LA, and one or two things I didn't really like in Boston)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (01:05): (and the other place we went to was some random place where my father was giving a paper at a conference, which was the whole reason for going)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (01:06): sighs
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (01:06): choices.
